bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to the Office of the Secretary of the War Department, September 18, 1940

div1.p: Hench requests old maps of Cuba. He offers his opinion on the roles of Reed and Finlay and the politics behind the debate.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to the Office of the Secretary of the War Department, September 18, 1940
div1.opener:
September 18, 1940
Office of the Secretary of the War Department
Washington, D. C.
Gentlemen:
div1.p:
I have been asked to give an address on the conquest of yellow fever, on
the occasion of the dedication of the Lazear Memorial Building, at Washington and
Jefferson College, Washington, Pennsylvania, October 26. In preparation for this
address, I recently visited Cuba to interview survivors of the United States Army
Yellow Fever Commission. While there, I was amazed to find that the Cuban government
has successfully carried on a campaign which ignors the work of Reed and the Army
Commission and insists that Finlay was robbed of his true glory, and definitely and
completely proved the cause of yellow fever. To further this campaign, Dominguez
wrote quite a book on this theme and just this week, the Oxford University Press in
New York has published a book by Finlay's son, to prove his father's contentions.

One of the problems I encountered in Cuba was connected with locating the
true site of Camp Lazear. The Cuban government has raised about $200,000 (so I
understand) to erect a memorial on the supposed site of Camp Lazear. I am absolutely
sure they have chosen the wrong place, and Moran (one of the original volunteers for
experimental yellow fever) and I were able to relocate the true site of the camp.
So interested were members of the Cuban government that the Secretary of Defense,
Dr. Ramos, and the Secretary of Health, Dr. Moya, asked me to submit a formal report
to the Cuban government on my findings.

I have had much help from many people in Cuba, and many in this country,
including General Kean and General Truby. The proper identification of Camp Lazear
and the blasting of the identification of the false camp involves getting a map as of
about 1900 of Camp Columbia, to show the site of the camp in relation to an adjacent
railroad track. I have had considerable correspondence with Mr. R. S. Webster,
Divisional Engineer of the Havana Railroad, who has shown me some maps and helped me
greatly, but we are both at the end of our rope as the old Havana maps show the railroad
but not the exact location of Camp Columbia in 1899, or of Columbia Barracks as of
1900 or 1901. Mr. Webster tells me that the United States, at the time of the first
intervention made maps of the whole island, including Camp Columbia and its environs.
I would appreciate it greatly if you would ask some member of your department to look
up these old maps for me, and if at all possible, send me copies of those which show the
exact site of Camp Columbia and Columbia Barracks. I am emboldened to ask for this real
favor, not for personal reasons, but because I want to see to it that the work and the
place where the Army Commission did the work is properly memorialized, and I am sure that
you, the War Department, will be most sympathetic to my plans.
div1.closer: Very truly yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
